--- title: "Auto-evaluation" page-layout: article jupyter: julia-1.11 --- We have included in this page a series of **quizzes** to help reinforce your learning. These quizzes are designed not only to test your understanding but also to provide you with an opportunity for **self-reflection**. After each quiz, take a moment to review your answers, reflect on what you've learned, and identify areas where you may need further clarification. Do not hesitate to reach out to your lecturer if any questions come up. ### Type Hierarchies ::: {.callout-caution collapse="true" icon=false} ## Quiz ::: {#fbf256c8 .cell execution_count=3} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=4} **Question 1. ::: {#4cd309b1 .cell execution_count=22} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=23} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: ### Type Conversion and Promotion ::: {.callout-caution collapse="true" icon=false} ## Quiz ::: {#f3115a88 .cell execution_count=24} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=25} **Question 1. What does the `convert` function do in Julia?** ::: :::

::: {#57051e16 .cell execution_count=25} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=26} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#8571d9b0 .cell execution_count=26} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=27} **Question 2. What is the output of the following code?** ::: :::

```julia println(round(Int, 3.14)) # Rounds 3.14 to the nearest integer, output: 3 println(floor(Int, 3.14)) # Floors 3.14 to the nearest integer, output: 3 println(convert(Float64, 5)) # Converts Int to Float64, output: 5.0 println(string(123)) # Converts Int to String, output: "123" ```

::: {#7f088209 .cell execution_count=27} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=28} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#a0af0161 .cell execution_count=28} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=29} **Question 3. What happens when an integer is assigned to a `Float64` variable in Julia?** ::: :::

```julia y::Float64 = 10 # The integer 10 is automatically converted to 10.0 (Float64) println(y) # Output: 10.0 ```

::: {#b9063fa1 .cell execution_count=29} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=30} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#22f5348c .cell execution_count=30} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=31} **Question 4. What does the `promote` function do in Julia?** ::: :::

```julia a, b = promote(3, 4.5) # Promotes both values to Float64 println(a) # Output: 3.0 println(b) # Output: 4.5 println(typeof(a)) # Output: Float64 println(typeof(b)) # Output: Float64 ```

::: {#f5590289 .cell execution_count=31} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=32} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#9124076c .cell execution_count=32} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=33} **Question 5. What will happen if we try to add an `Int` and a `String` in Julia?** ::: :::

```julia println(3 + "Hello") # Attempting to add Int and String ```

::: {#328a300e .cell execution_count=33} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=34} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: ### Special Types ::: {.callout-caution collapse="true" icon=false} ## Quiz ::: {#b042f69a .cell execution_count=35} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=36} **Question 1. What does the `Nothing` type represent in Julia?** ::: :::

::: {#977ca954 .cell execution_count=36} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=37} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#84a9b8d6 .cell execution_count=37} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=38} **Question 2. What is the result of calling the following function in Julia?** ::: :::

```julia # Example of a function that returns `Nothing` function print_message(msg::String) println(msg) return nothing # Explicitly returns `nothing` end result = print_message("Hello!") println(result === nothing) # Output: true ```

::: {#e19e7738 .cell execution_count=38} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=39} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#cb437f88 .cell execution_count=39} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=40} **Question 3. What is the advantage of using `Any` as a type in Julia?** ::: :::

```julia # Example of using `Any` as a type function describe(value::Any) println("Value: ", value) println("Type: ", typeof(value)) end describe(42) # Works with Int describe("Hello") # Works with String describe(3.14) # Works with Float64 ```

::: {#8a822900 .cell execution_count=40} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=41} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#39871dd2 .cell execution_count=41} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=42} **Question 4. What does the following code do in Julia?** ::: :::

```julia data = [1, 2, missing, 4, 5] for item in data if item === missing println("Missing data detected.") else println("Value: ", item) end end ```

::: {#bb33ae4d .cell execution_count=42} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=43} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#4d135a1b .cell execution_count=43} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=44} **Question 5. What is the purpose of the `skipmissing` function in Julia?** ::: :::

```julia using Statistics # Example array with missing values data = [1, 2, missing, 4, 5, missing, 7] # Summing values while skipping missing entries sum_no_missing = sum(skipmissing(data)) println("Sum without missing values: ", sum_no_missing) # Output: 19 # Calculating the mean while skipping missing values mean_no_missing = mean(skipmissing(data)) println("Mean without missing values: ", mean_no_missing) # Output: 3.8 ```

::: {#c607e1ee .cell execution_count=44} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=45} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#c8edacc2 .cell execution_count=45} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=46} **Question 6. What is the main use of the `Missing` type in Julia?** ::: :::

```julia # Example of using `missing` in an array data = [1, 2, missing, 4, 5] # Check for missing values in the array for item in data if item === missing println("Missing data detected.") else println("Value: ", item) end end ```

::: {#9c53d306 .cell execution_count=46} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=47} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: ### Union Types ::: {.callout-caution collapse="true" icon=false} ## Quiz ::: {#e8654af1 .cell execution_count=48} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=49} **Question 1. What is a `Union` type in Julia?** ::: :::

::: {#ff7fd8de .cell execution_count=49} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=50} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#616eaee5 .cell execution_count=50} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=51} **Question 2. What is the output of the following code?** ::: :::

```julia function process_number(x::Union{Int, Float64}) println("The input is: ", x) end process_number(5) # Works with an Int process_number(3.14) # Works with a Float64 ```

::: {#070e07b9 .cell execution_count=51} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=52} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#e37d946f .cell execution_count=52} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=53} **Question 3. Which of the following scenarios would benefit from using a `Union` type?** ::: :::

```julia # Example using Union to handle multiple types in a function function add_one(x::Union{Int, Float64}) return x + 1 end println(add_one(3)) # Output: 4 (Int) println(add_one(2.5)) # Output: 3.5 (Float64) ```

::: {#85176296 .cell execution_count=53} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=54} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#238bdfa2 .cell execution_count=54} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=55} **Question 4. What happens when a value of a type not listed in the `Union` is passed to a function?** ::: :::

```julia function process_number(x::Union{Int, Float64}) println("The input is: ", x) end process_number("Hello") # Trying to pass a String ```

::: {#eee681f0 .cell execution_count=55} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=56} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#6565ff44 .cell execution_count=56} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=57} **Question 5. How does the `add_one` function handle both `Int` and `Float64` types?** ::: :::

```julia function add_one(x::Union{Int, Float64}) return x + 1 end println(add_one(3)) # Output: 4 (Int) println(add_one(2.5)) # Output: 3.5 (Float64) ```

::: {#0423de4a .cell execution_count=57} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=58} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: ### Type Annotations and Declarations ::: {.callout-caution collapse="true" icon=false} ## Quiz ::: {#799ca99f .cell execution_count=59} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=60} **Question 1. What is the primary purpose of type annotations in Julia?** ::: :::

::: {#c007d01e .cell execution_count=60} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=61} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#dd570752 .cell execution_count=61} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=62} **Question 2. Which of the following correctly applies a type annotation to a variable?** ::: :::

::: {#f800fa2a .cell execution_count=62} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=63} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#82396dd2 .cell execution_count=63} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=64} **Question 3. What will happen if the following code is executed?** ::: :::

```julia function add(a::Int, b::Int) return a + b end add(3, "4") ```

::: {#1fd15f10 .cell execution_count=64} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=65} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#3702059b .cell execution_count=65} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=66} **Question 4. In Julia, what will the following code output?** ::: :::

```julia function multiply(a::Int, b::Int)::Int return a * b end multiply(3, 4) ```

::: {#fc5d2511 .cell execution_count=66} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=67} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: ### Parametric Types ::: {.callout-caution collapse="true" icon=false} ## Quiz ::: {#311c9f0c .cell execution_count=68} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=69} **Question 1. What is a parametric type in Julia?** ::: :::

::: {#75339d99 .cell execution_count=69} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=70} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#16638c3e .cell execution_count=70} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=71} **Question 2. What is the role of `T` and `S` in the `Pair` struct example?** ::: :::

```julia struct Pair{T, S} first::T second::S end pair1 = Pair(1, "apple") # Pair of Int and String pair2 = Pair(3.14, true) # Pair of Float64 and Bool ```

::: {#0703b6ac .cell execution_count=71} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=72} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#6b9c7f41 .cell execution_count=72} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=73} **Question 3. What happens when you instantiate `Pair(1, 'apple')` in the provided code?** ::: :::

```julia pair1 = Pair(1, "apple") # Pair of Int and String ```

::: {#e2018868 .cell execution_count=73} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=74} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#9cf5d3ff .cell execution_count=74} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=75} **Question 4. What is the benefit of using parametric types like `AbstractContainer{T}`?** ::: :::

```julia abstract type AbstractContainer{T} end struct VectorContainer{T} <: AbstractContainer{T} data::Vector{T} end struct SetContainer{T} <: AbstractContainer{T} data::Set{T} end ```

::: {#6bbe9e5e .cell execution_count=75} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=76} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#40bbf77b .cell execution_count=76} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=77} **Question 5. What does the `print_container_info` function do?** ::: :::

```julia function print_container_info(container::AbstractContainer{T}) where T println("Container holds values of type: ", T) end ```

::: {#f40197f2 .cell execution_count=77} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=78} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ::: {#f08b4c14 .cell execution_count=78} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=79} **Question 6. What is the purpose of `AbstractContainer{T}` in the code example?** ::: :::

``` ::: ::: ::: {#6b6e83a6 .cell execution_count=80} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=81} **Question 7. What would be the output of `print_container_info(vec)` if `vec` is `VectorContainer([1, 2, 3])`?** ::: :::

``` ::: ::: ::: ### Errors and Exception Handling ::: {.callout-caution collapse="true" icon=false} ## Quiz ::: {#93d5ccc4 .cell execution_count=85} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=86} **Question 1. Which error type is raised when an index is out of bounds in an array?** ::: :::

::: {#887b2a3d .cell execution_count=86} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=87} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#80a39242 .cell execution_count=87} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=88} **Question 2. What does the following code do in Julia?** ::: :::

```julia function divide(a, b) if b == 0 throw(DivideError()) end return a / b end ```

::: {#74631b60 .cell execution_count=88} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=89} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#272b94fc .cell execution_count=89} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=90} **Question 3. What happens when the following `try`/`catch` block is executed?** ::: :::

```julia try println(divide(10, 0)) # Will raise an error catch e println("Error: ", e) # Handles the error end ```

::: {#e829f90e .cell execution_count=90} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=91} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#d610aab1 .cell execution_count=91} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=92} **Question 4. What is the purpose of the `finally` block in Julia's exception handling?** ::: :::

::: {#dded09c3 .cell execution_count=92} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=93} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#5f2ea4f6 .cell execution_count=93} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=94} **Question 5. What is the output of the following code?** ::: :::

```julia function safe_file_read(filename::String) file = nothing try file = open(filename, "r") data = read(file, String) return data catch e println("An error occurred: ", e) finally if file !== nothing close(file) println("File closed.") end end end # Test with a valid file println(safe_file_read("example.txt")) # Test with an invalid file println(safe_file_read("nonexistent.txt")) ```

::: {#8bd85e6c .cell execution_count=94} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=95} ```{=html}
Select an item
``` ::: ::: ::: {#252d6f04 .cell execution_count=95} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display .cell-output-markdown execution_count=96} **Question 6. Which of the following is an appropriate use case for the `finally` block?** ::: :::

Select an item
``` ::: ::: :::
